text.author: Wiktionary
text.title: trust
text.summary1: (human1) This dictionary entry for the word 'trust' provides its etymology from Middle English 'trust' and Proto-Indo-European *deru- 'be firm', cognates such as Danish trøst, pronunciations like /trʌst/ and /trʊst/ and synonyms, antonyms, usage examples and definitions as a noun (e.g. 'confidence', 'hope'), senses in computing and law, and as a verb meaning to have faith or believe.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) This dictionary entry for 'trust' traces its etymology from Middle English and Germanic roots, provides IPA pronunciations, and defines it as a noun meaning confidence/reliance, a verb meaning to place confidence in someone/something, and an obsolete adjective meaning secure/faithful, with various legal and financial uses.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) This entry for the word 'trust' details its pronunciation /trʌst/, etymology tracing back to Middle English and Proto-Indo-European roots, meanings such as confidence, hope, and legal arrangements, usage as both noun and verb, related terms like faith and belief, and antonyms including distrust and mistrust.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The English word "trust" originates from Old English and Proto-Germanic roots, ultimately tracing back to Proto-Indo-European *deru-, with various meanings including confidence, protection, and reliance.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct) The entry defines "trust" in English, tracing its etymology from Old Norse to Proto-Indo-European, providing its various uses including confidence, hope, and legal obligations, with detailed pronunciations and synonyms.
